Generated Narrative: RequestGroup 257

instantiatesCanonical: Decision to Screen

status: Draft

intent: Proposal

subject: Jane Doe

action

id

SDMContinueScreeningAge

title: Shared decision making to continue screening based on age

description: Decision to continue screening mammography in average risk women age 75 years or older should be based on shared decision-making. The USPSTF concludes that the evidence is insufficient to determine the balance of benefits and harms of screening mammography in women 75 years or older.

code: Shared decision making to continue screening

Documentations

-TypeLabelDisplayCitationUrl
*CitationUSPSTFScreening for Breast Cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement

US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for Breast Cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement. JAMA. Published online April 30, 2024.

https://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/uspstf/recommendation/breast-cancer-screening

resource: Bundle: type = collection

action

id

SDMDelayScreeningLactating

title: Shared decision making to delay screening based on lactation status

description: There is no contraindication to screening mammography during lactation, however sensitivity and specificity are decreased. For average risk patients, consider a short delay in routine breast imaging until after lactation, particularly if they are not planning prolonged breastfeeding.

code: Shared decision making to consider delay in screening

resource: Bundle: type = collection

action

id

ACSMammoAvgRiskAgeOver54

Recommendation Flag Extension: Overdue

title: Biennial screening mammogram after age 54

description: Biennial screening mammogram is recommended after age 54. Women 55 and older can switch to a mammogram every other year, or they can choose to continue yearly mammograms. Screening should continue as long as a woman is in good health and is expected to live at least 10 more years.

code: MG Breast Screening

Documentations

-TypeLabelDisplayCitationUrl
*CitationACSBreast Cancer Screening for Women at Average Risk: 2015 Guideline Update From the American Cancer Society

Saslow D, Boetes C, Burke W, Harms S, Leach MO, Lehman CD, Morris E, Pisano E, Schnall M, Sener S, Smith RA, Warner E, Yaffe M, Andrews KS, Russell CA; American Cancer Society Breast Cancer Advisory Group. American Cancer Society guidelines for breast screening with MRI as an adjunct to mammography. CA Cancer J Clin. 2007 Mar-Apr;57(2):75-89.

https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2463262

timing: Events: 1985-01-01 , Once per 2 years

action.title: Shared decision making to continue screening based on age
action.description:
Decision to continue screening mammography in average risk women age 75 years or older should be based on shared decision-making.

The USPSTF concludes that the evidence is insufficient to determine the balance of benefits and harms of screening mammography in women 75 years or older.

coding.display: Shared decision making to continue screening

documentation.display: Screening for Breast Cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement
documentation.citation: US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for Breast Cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement. JAMA. Published online April 30, 2024.

action.title: Shared decision making to delay screening based on lactation status
action.description: There is no contraindication to screening mammography during lactation, however sensitivity and specificity are decreased. For average risk patients, consider a short delay in routine breast imaging until after lactation, particularly if they are not planning prolonged breastfeeding.

coding.display: Shared decision making to consider delay in screening

action.title: Biennial screening mammogram after age 54
action.description:
Biennial screening mammogram is recommended after age 54.

Women 55 and older can switch to a mammogram every other year, or they can choose to continue yearly mammograms. Screening should continue as long as a woman is in good health and is expected to live at least 10 more years.
